haven't seen all of these in the game, but i would expect:
- electric can't be paralyzed
- steel and poison can't be poisoned
- fire can't be burnt
- ice can't be frozen (frostbitten now?)
- grass isn't affected by powder moves

don't think there's a floating immunity to ground

so it doesn't matter that bite doesn't have a 30% flinch chance, because it's more interesting that it gives a bunch of pokémon access to dark damage

and alongside that we have all the more recent type rules like—  well let me just make a list

even in gen 1, types were hit or miss because half the types basically had no moves.  they've fixed that over the years and added some other stuff, but they also added a bunch of other mechanics at the same time that kind of overshadowed types

(oh, right: no held items)

overall it seems like they optimized for getting in, through, and out of battles really quickly, which...  makes sense!

but a cool side effect is that the game feels much more reliant on types again, maybe moreso than any game in the main series—

- no abilities
- despite that multi battles are really easy to end up in, there don't seem to be any multi-target moves
- multi-hit moves are instead a lingering damage effect (as is stealth rock)
- weather effects are simpler

pokémon legends arceus has streamlined the hell out of the battle system and i am here for it

things i have noticed:
- no "accuracy down" moves, very few "evasion down"
- moves always impact atk/spatk and def/spdef the same way
- no flinching
- sleep is only a chance to fail

@rakslice i suspect i was single-digit-aged at the time so it's hard to know how accurate this is, but i remember feeling like it wasn't so much a prescribed curriculum as "this teacher really, really likes wordperfect for dos"

i think it's cool to discover something basic i take for granted and wonder what would happen if i swapped it out, and i think that's pretty much the basis of learning anything (other than a completely new field you've never heard of before)

the key is that these things are decisions made by people, and there are reasons for them, but there are also reasons you might make different decisions

cf: people Good At Computers haven't memorized Word's toolbar, we just guess at where someone might think to put something

people who only know C struggle to understand arg passing in javascript

people who only know decimal struggle to understand binary

they have baked-in assumptions about How Things Fundamentally Work that they don't know how to find, let alone question

if you teach one of a thing, you leave a lot of students with the impression that that's the only kind of thing, that it is the archetypical thing, that all different things are deviating and confusing.  if you teach several things, you teach them to navigate a possibility space
my hot take is that school should be much less about concrete things and much more about abstract things

@NickADobos @jlazaroff @glyph @thomasjwebb (of course the marginal cost isn't quite literally zero, since there is bandwidth and cpu time.  but those are so cheap that in most cases they are a rounding error, and if they aren't, you are probably not an indie artist)

@NickADobos @jlazaroff @glyph @thomasjwebb but then we have the internet, where the marginal cost is zero.  so what should prices be?  also zero?  that doesn't cover fixed costs...  but a lot of creative folks are okay with that, which brings us things like open source software

@NickADobos @jlazaroff @glyph @thomasjwebb often the cost of a product is primarily based on its marginal cost, with any fixed cost (upfront costs not dependent on how many products you create, like rent on your factory) amortized over a large number of sales.  this is why producing in volume means lower prices

@NickADobos @jlazaroff @glyph @thomasjwebb i am begging you to look up some basic economics terms.  "marginal cost" is the cost of creating 1 more of your product, assuming you have already made N of them.  if your product is digital then the margin cost is zero: it exists and copies cost nothing
